cards.front: What is the 2D cross product of two vectors?
cards.back:
The signed area of the parallelogram they span.

Positive: second vector is counterclockwise from first
Negative: second vector is clockwise from first

Computed as det([v₁ w₁; v₂ w₂])

cards.front: What is the 3D cross product v × w?
cards.back:
A new vector that is:
1. Perpendicular to both v and w
2. Has magnitude equal to the area of the parallelogram formed by v and w
3. Direction determined by the right-hand rule

cards.front: How do you apply the right-hand rule for cross products?
cards.back:
Point your forefinger toward the first vector v.
Point your middle finger toward the second vector w.
Your thumb points in the direction of v × w.

cards.front:
Is the cross product commutative?

Does v × w = w × v?
cards.back:
No! The cross product is anti-commutative.

v × w = -(w × v)

Swapping the order flips the sign (reverses direction).

cards.front: What happens to the cross product when vectors are parallel or perpendicular?
cards.back:
Parallel vectors: cross product is zero (no parallelogram area)

Perpendicular vectors: cross product magnitude is maximal (||v|| × ||w||)

cards.front:
How does scaling affect the cross product?

(kv) × w = ?
cards.back:
(kv) × w = k(v × w)

Scaling one vector by k scales the cross product by k (because it scales the parallelogram area by k).
